{"uri": "2024-06-377426377", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "16:13:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T16:13:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T16:13:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/rex-heuermann-serial-killer-gilgo-beach-long-island-fifth-victim-1907575", "title": "Gilgo Beach serial killer: New details about alleged suspect Rex Heuermann", "body": "Investigators have linked a possible fifth victim to Rex Heuermann, the alleged Gilgo Beach serial killer, according to reports from local media outlets.\n\nThe 60-year-old was first arrested in July 2023 for the deaths of four women whose remains were found in burlap sacks along the Ocean Parkway in New York over a decade ago.\n\nHeuermann faces charges in connection to the murders of Melissa Barthelemy, Megan Waterman, Amber Lynn Costello and Maureen Brainard-Barnes - also known as \"The Gilgo Four.\"\n\nThe announcement of a potential fifth victim comes weeks after authorities returned to Heuermann's Long Island home. At least half a dozen law enforcement agents were spotted in Heuermann's driveway on May 20. Cars, including state trooper vans, lined the street along the Massapequa Park neighborhood.\n\nRobert Macedonio, who represents Heuermann's estranged wife, told Newsday the inspection seemed to focus in the basement of the Long Island house.\n\nThe New York State Police previously told Newsweek it would not comment on the situation.\n\nThe Suffolk County District Attorney's Office did not respond immediately to Newsweek's request for comment.\n\nWho is Rex Heuermann?\n\nHeuermann graduated from the same local high school as actor Billy Baldwin who tweeted after the news broke about his 1981 classmate's arrest, describing it as \"mind-boggling.\"\n\nAfter getting a bachelor's degree from the New York Institute of Technology, Heuermann started his architecture firm RH Consultants in 1994. He did most of his architectural work in New York City, according to a company biography and the firm's website.\n\nHeuermann is currently being held at the Riverhead Correctional Facility in Suffolk County, about 50 miles from his home.\n\nThe Gilgo Four\n\nThe hunt for a possible serial killer started in 2010 when 11 sets of human remains were discovered along a property on Gilgo Beach in Suffolk County. Law enforcement first started searching along Ocean Parkway after Shannan Gilbert, a 24-year-old sex worker from New Jersey, vanished in 2010.\n\nThe search first turned up the remains of Barthelemy, Waterman, Lynn Costello and Brainard-Barnes. All the women were in their mid-20s.\n\nPolice found additional remains, including those belonging to Jessica Taylor and Valerie Mack as well as a female toddler, Asian male, and an unidentified woman who is believed to be the toddler's mother.\n\nThe case has long mystified police, and it captured the public's attention when Netflix released a film in 2020 called Lost Girls that was based on the murders.\n\nDetectives finally nabbed Heuermann in 2023 after he tossed a pizza box with leftover crust into a Manhattan trash can. The DNA from the crust matched genetic material found on the women's remains.\n\nHeuermann's allegations go beyond killing these women. He apparently also tormented their families. Prosecutors have revealed he used a victim's cellphone to taunt her family. In one case, he admitted to the murder. {"uri": "8164759486", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "13:23:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T13:23:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T13:22:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://abc7ny.com/post/gilgo-beach-suspect-serial-killer-rex-heuermann-murders/14917073/", "title": "Suspected Gilgo Beach serial killer Rex Heuermann charged in deaths of 2 more women", "body": "SUFFOLK COUNTY, Long Island (WABC) -- Suspected Gilgo Beach serial killer Rex Heuermann is back in court Thursday and is now charged in the deaths of two more women.\n\nHeuermann, 60, is charged in the 2003 death of Jessica Taylor. Her remains were partially found near Gilgo Beach and partially found in a wooded area of Manorville, farther east on Long Island.\n\nHe was also charged in the death of Sandra Castilla, whose killing was long thought to be the work of another person.\n\n(Video in media player above from previous report)\n\nHer remains were found in North Sea, in the town of Southampton. She was killed in 1993, which is a significant expansion of the timeline of Heuermann's alleged serial killing.\n\nALSO READ: Gilgo Beach murders: Complete timeline of events leading up to Rex Heuermann's arrest\n\nThis comes after recent searches in the woods in Manorville and the North Sea, and in Heuermann's Massapequa Park home.\n\nEvidence is believed to have been recovered from the basement, resulting in the new charges.\n\nThere has been a sweeping expansion of the investigation into Heuermann, a former New York City architect, following his arrest last summer.\n\nAt least 11 sets of human remains have been found in Long Island's Suffolk County, including the four women Heuermann is accused of killing: Megan Waterman, Melissa Barthelemy, Amber Costello, and Maureen Brainard-Barnes.\n\nTheir remains were found near Gilgo Beach along Ocean Parkway.\n\nHeuermann has pleaded not guilty to all murder charges and is being held without bail.\n\nHave a breaking news tip or an idea for a story we should cover? {"uri": "8165163438", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "18:01:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T18:01:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T18:01:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://ktar.com/story/5576104/man-charged-in-gilgo-beach-serial-killings-kept-blueprint-of-crimes-on-computer-prosecutors-say/", "title": "Man charged in Gilgo Beach serial killings kept 'blueprint' of crimes on computer, prosecutors say", "body": "RIVERHEAD, N.Y. (AP) -- The New York architect accused of murdering multiple women and leaving their corpses scattered along the Long Island coast kept a \"blueprint\" of his crimes on his computer, prosecutors revealed Thursday as they brought charges against Rex Heuermann in two more killings.\n\nHeuermann, 60, appeared before a judge to be arraigned in the deaths of Jessica Taylor and Sandra Costilla, two young women who were long suspected of being the victims of men preying on sex workers. He had previously been charged with murdering four other women in a string of deaths known as the Gilgo Beach serial killings.\n\nTaylor disappeared in 2003. Costilla was killed 30 years ago, in 1993, and her inclusion in the case indicates that prosecutors now believe Heuermann was killing women for much longer than previously thought.\n\nThe new charges came after recent police searches of Heuermann's Massapequa Park home and a wooded area on Long Island tied to the investigation.\n\nIn a court filing, prosecutors said they were able to use new forensic testing methods to match hairs found on or near the vicinity of both victims to a DNA profile that is a likely match to Heuermann. Additionally, prosecutors say they recovered a file on a hard drive in his basement used to \"methodically blueprint\" his killings.\n\nThe all-caps document features a series of checklists with tasks to complete before, during and after the killings, as well as practical lessons for \"next time.\" Among the dozens of entries written are reminders to clean the bodies and destroy evidence, to \"get sleep before hunt\" and to \"have story set.\"\n\nOne section, titled \"things to remember,\" appears to highlight lessons from previous killings, prosecutors said, such as using heavier rope and limiting noise in order to maximize \"play time.\" A \"body prep\" checklist includes, among other items, a note to \"remove head and hands.\"\n\nProsecutors believe that entry may connect Heuermann to yet another victim, Valerie Mack, whose partial skeletal remains were discovered near the body of Taylor after her disappearance in 2000.\n\nHeuermann has not been charged in the death of Mack. But asked during a news conference after Thursday's hearing if he was a suspect, District Attorney Ray Tierney replied, \"That's fair to say.\"\n\nHeuermann pleaded not guilty to killing Taylor and Costilla during the hearing and was ordered held without bail. His lawyer, Michael Brown, said outside court that Heuermann is \"obviously in a bad place in terms of the new charges.\"\n\nAfterward, Tierney said the additional charges provide \"some small measure of closure\" for the victims' families.\n\nSince late 2010, police have been investigating the deaths of at least 10 people -- mostly female sex workers -- whose remains were discovered along an isolated highway not far from Gilgo Beach on Long Island's south shore.\n\nThose victims disappeared over a span of at least 14 years. Vexed detectives made only halting progress in identifying possible suspects. Investigators long said it was likely that not all of the deaths were the work of the same killer. Some of the victims vanished in the mid-1990s. Investigators concluded that an 11th person who disappeared in 2010 from the barrier island community of Oak Beach had accidentally drowned.\n\nHeuermann, who lived across a bay from where the bodies were found, was arrested last July. Prosecutors said a new investigative task force used mobile phone location data and DNA samples to link the architect to some of the victims. He was charged with killing four of the women: Megan Waterman, Melissa Barthelemy, Amber Lynn Costello and Maureen Brainard-Barnes.\n\nInvestigators who searched Heuermann's home extensively and dug up his yard last summer returned to the house last month and spent nearly a week searching it again. They focused their efforts mostly in the basement, according to a lawyer for Heuermann's wife.\n\nThat followed a search in April of a wooded area in Manorville, about 40 miles (65 kilometers) east of Heuermann's home, and in the Southampton hamlet of North Sea, where Costilla's remains were discovered decades ago.\n\nTierney said the planning document was recovered in March, providing the impetus for the recent searches.\n\nProsecutors also said they found a book in Heuermann's possession by the retired FBI agent John Douglas, \"The Cases That Haunt Us.\" They say the planning document referenced specific pages in another work by Douglas, \"Mind Hunter,\" that allude to the personality types of serial killers and profiles of those who use mutilation and sexual violence.\n\nJessica Taylor, 20, vanished in 2003 while working as an escort in New York City. Some of her remains were discovered in Manorville that year. Other remains were found during a 2011 search of the beach scrub by the side of Ocean Parkway, the road where the other Gilgo Beach victims were found.\n\nTaylor's mother, Elizabeth Baczkiel, was at the courthouse for Thursday's hearing. She held up childhood photos of her daughter but didn't speak to reporters. Her lawyer, Gloria Allred, read a statement from Baczkiel in which she described her daughter as \"loving, compassionate and so funny,\" and said she would have made a great mother.\n\n\"My darling daughter, you will never be forgotten,\" the statement said. \"You will forever be in our hearts.\"\n\nValerie Mack, 24, who had been working as an escort in Philadelphia, disappeared in 2000 and was last seen by her family in Port Republic, New Jersey, near Atlantic City. Some of her skeletal remains were discovered that year in the Manorville woods. More of her remains were found in 2011 during the search around Gilgo Beach.\n\nInitially known as \"Jane Doe No. 6,\" Mack's remains went unidentified until 2020, when genetic testing revealed her identity.\n\nCostilla was 28 when she was killed and had lived in New York City.\n\nA decade ago, Suffolk County prosecutors said publicly that they believed Costilla had been killed by John Bittrolff, an area carpenter who was convicted of murdering two other women whose bodies were found in the same part of Long Island.\n\nBut Bittrolff was never charged with Costilla's death due to lack of evidence. He insists he didn't kill anyone and his lawyers didn't immediately respond to phone and email messages seeking comment Thursday.\n\nHeuermann's lawyer, Brown, said he planned to request the prosecution's files on Bittrolff.\n\n\"Quite frankly, the police department and the district attorney's office all had the finger pointed at Bittrolff for that murder,\" he said. ___", "source": {"uri": "8165035306", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "16:22:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T16:22:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T16:21:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.wtnh.com/news/ap-us-news/ap-gilgo-beach-killings-suspect-due-in-court-as-prosecutors-tout-significant-development-in-case/", "title": "Man charged in Gilgo Beach serial killings kept document used to 'blueprint' crimes, prosecutors say", "body": "RIVERHEAD, N.Y. (AP) -- The New York architect previously accused of killing four women and leaving their corpses scattered along a coastal highway was charged Thursday in the deaths of two more, after prosecutors said they gathered new DNA evidence and found a planning document he had used to \"blueprint\" his crimes.\n\nRex Heuermann, 60, appeared before a judge on the eastern end of Long Island to face charges that he killed Jessica Taylor and Sandra Costilla, two young women who were long suspected of being the victims of men preying on sex workers.\n\nTaylor disappeared in 2003. Costilla was killed in 1993. The new charges came just days after police finished extensive searches of Heuermann's Massapequa Park home and a wooded area on Long Island tied to the investigation of a string of deaths known as the Gilgo Beach serial killings.\n\nIn a court filing, prosecutors said they were able to use new forensic testing methods to match hairs found on or near the vicinity of both victims to a DNA profile that is a likely match to Heuermann. Additionally, prosecutors say they recovered a \"planning document\" on a hard drive in his basement used to \"methodically blueprint\" his killings.\n\nThe all-caps document features a series of checklists with tasks to complete before, during and after the killings, as well as practical lessons for \"next time.\" Among the dozens of entries written are reminders to clean the bodies and destroy evidence, to \"get sleep before hunt\" and to \"have story set.\"\n\nOne section, titled \"things to remember,\" appears to highlight lessons from previous killings, prosecutors said, such as using heavier rope and limiting noise in order to maximize \"play time.\" A \"body prep\" checklist includes, among other items, a note to \"remove head and hands.\"\n\nProsecutors believe that entry may connect Heuermann to yet another victim, Valerie Mack, whose partial skeletal remains were discovered near the body of Taylor after her disappearance in 2000.\n\nHeuermann has not been charged in the death of Mack. But asked during a news conference after Thursday's hearing if he was a suspect, District Attorney Ray Tierney replied, \"That's fair to say.\"\n\nHe added that investigators are still working the case, noting that the \"method of the crime scene\" in Mack's killing was consistent with those of the other victims.\n\nHeuermann pleaded not guilty to killing Taylor and Costilla during the hearing and was ordered held without bail.\n\nAfterward, Tierney said the new charges provide \"some small measure of closure\" for the victims' families.\n\nThe charges involving Costilla, who was killed 30 years ago, indicate that prosecutors believe Heuermann was killing victims for much longer longer than previously thought. Unlike the other victims, Costilla's remains were not among those discovered at Gilgo Beach, but were found in a wooded area in Southampton, Long Island.\n\nSince late 2010, police have been investigating the deaths of at least 10 people -- mostly female sex workers -- whose remains were discovered along an isolated highway not far from Gilgo Beach on Long Island's south shore.\n\nThe victims had disappeared over a span of at least 14 years. Vexed police officers made only halting progress in identifying possible suspects. Investigators long said it was likely that not all of the deaths were the work of the same killer. Some of the victims disappeared in the mid-1990s. Investigators concluded that an 11th person who disappeared in 2010 from the barrier island community of Oak Beach had accidentally drowned.\n\nHeuermann, who lived across a bay from where the bodies were found, was arrested last July. Prosecutors said a new investigative task force used mobile phone location data and DNA samples to link the architect to some of the victims. He was charged with killing four of the women: Megan Waterman, Melissa Barthelemy, Amber Lynn Costello and Maureen Brainard-Barnes.\n\nInvestigators who had searched Heuermann's home extensively and dug up his yard last summer returned to the house again last month and spent nearly a week searching it again. They focused their efforts mostly in the basement, according to a lawyer for Heuermann's wife.\n\nThat followed a search in April of a wooded area in Manorville, about 40 miles (65 kilometers) east of Heuermann's home, linked to another Gilgo Beach victim.\n\nTierney said the planning document was recovered in March of this year, providing the impetus for the recent searches at the suspect's home and in Manorville.\n\nProsecutors also said they found a book in Heuermann's possession by the retired FBI agent John Douglas, \"The Cases That Haunt Us.\" They say the planning document referenced specific pages in another work by Douglas, \"Mind Hunter,\" that allude to the personality types of serial killers and profiles of those who use mutilation and sexual violence.\n\nJessica Taylor, 20, vanished in 2003 while working as an escort in New York City. Some of her remains were discovered in Manorville that year. Other remains were found in a 2011 search of the beach scrub by the side of Ocean Parkway, the road where the other Gilgo Beach victims were found.\n\nValerie Mack, 24, who had been working as an escort in Philadelphia, disappeared in 2000 and was last seen by her family in Port Republic, New Jersey, near Atlantic City. Some of her skeletal remains were discovered that same year in the Manorville woods. More of her remains were found in 2011 in the search around Gilgo Beach.\n\nInitially known as \"Jane Doe No. 6,\" Mack's remains had been unidentified for years until genetic testing revealed her identity in 2020.\n\nInvestigators in April also spent days searching a property in the eastern Long Island hamlet of North Sea, where Costilla's body was discovered in 1993. Costilla was 28 when she was killed and had lived in New York City.\n\nA decade ago, Suffolk County prosecutors said publicly that they believed Costilla had been killed by a carpenter who lived in the area, John Bittrolff, who was convicted of murdering two other women whose bodies had been found on the same part of Long Island. But Bittrolff was never charged with Costilla's death due to lack of evidence. He insists he is innocent of any murders.\n\nHeuermann's lawyer and the lawyers separately representing his wife and two adult children declined to comment.\n\nHeuermann, who has been in custody since his arrest, has pleaded not guilty. He had been set to return to court on July 30 for a status hearing. No trial date has been set.\n\nFollow Philip Marcelo at twitter.com/philmarcelo.", "source": {"uri": "wtnh.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WTNH"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-381077435", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "15:43:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T15:43:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T15:41:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/06/06/gilgo-beach-serial-killing-suspect-charged-with-2-more-murders/", "title": "Gilgo Beach serial killing suspect charged with 2 more murders", "body": "RIVERHEAD, N.Y. -- The New York architect previously accused of killing four women and leaving their corpses scattered along a coastal highway was charged Thursday in the deaths of two more, after prosecutors said they gathered new DNA evidence and found a computer document he had used to \"blueprint\" his crimes.\n\nAlleged Gilgo serial killer Rex Heuermann appears Feb. 6 in court in Riverhead, N.Y. James Carbone/Newsday via AP\n\nRex Heuermann, 60, appeared before a judge on the eastern end of Long Island to face charges that he killed Jessica Taylor and Sandra Costilla, two young women who were long suspected of being the victims of men preying on sex workers.\n\nTaylor disappeared in 2003. Costilla was killed in 1993. The new charges came just days after police finished extensive searches of Heuermann's Massapequa Park home and a wooded area on Long Island tied to the investigation of a string of deaths known as the Gilgo Beach serial killings.\n\nIn a court filing, prosecutors said they were able to use new forensic testing methods to match hairs found on or near the vicinity of both victims to a DNA profile that is a likely match to Heuermann. Additionally, prosecutors say they discovered a \"planning document\" on the hard drive found in his basement used to \"methodically blueprint\" his killings.\n\nRelated\n\nFor the first time, daughter of Long Island serial killer victim from Maine speaks out\n\nThe document lays out a set of tasks to complete before, during and after killings, including checking the weather and setting up a staging area. It also has a place to note practical lessons for \"next time.\"\n\nOne section, titled \"BODY PREP,\" includes guidance to \"REMOVE HEAD AND HANDS,\" as well as tattoos and trace DNA, and to wash the bodies. Another section, \"THINGS TO REMEMBER,\" appears to highlight lessons from previous killings that should be heeded, according to prosecutors. The entries describe the importance of sleeping properly \"BEFORE HUNT,\" using thick rope, and limiting noise to increase \"PLAY TIME.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHeuermann pleaded not guilty at the court hearing and was ordered held without bail.\n\nSuffolk County District Attorney Ray Tierney planned to hold a news conference following the court hearing.\n\nThe charges involving Costilla, who was killed 30 years ago, indicate that prosecutors believe Heuermann was killing victims for much longer longer than previously thought. Prosecutors say one entry in the planning documents suggested he was involved in the death of another woman, Valerie Mack, who was found dismembered in the same vicinity as Taylor. Heuermann has not been charged in the death of Mack, who disappeared in 2000.\n\nSince late 2010, police have been investigating the deaths of at least 10 people - mostly female sex workers - whose remains were discovered along an isolated highway not far from Gilgo Beach on Long Island's south shore.\n\nThe victims had disappeared over a span of at least 14 years. Vexed police officers made only halting progress in identifying possible suspects. Investigators long said it was likely that not all of the deaths were the work of the same killer. Some of the victims disappeared in the mid-1990s. Investigators concluded that an 11th person who disappeared in 2010 from the barrier island community of Oak Beach had accidentally drowned.\n\nHeuermann, who lived across a bay from where the bodies were found, was arrested last July. Prosecutors said a new investigative task force used mobile phone location data and DNA samples to link the architect to some of the victims. He was charged with killing four of the women: Megan Waterman of Scarborough, Melissa Barthelemy, Amber Lynn Costello and Maureen Brainard-Barnes.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nInvestigators who had searched Heuermann's home extensively and dug up his yard last summer returned to the house again last month and spent nearly a week searching it again. They focused their efforts mostly in the basement, according to a lawyer for Heuermann's wife.\n\nThat followed a search in April of a wooded area in Manorville, about 40 miles east of Heuermann's home, linked to another Gilgo Beach victim.\n\nIn addition to the hard drive, prosecutors say they found a book in Heuermann's possession by the retired FBI agent John Douglas, \"The Cases That Haunt Us.\" They say the planning document also referenced specific pages in another work by Douglas, \"Mind Hunter,\" that allude to the personality types of serial killers and personality profiles of those who use mutilation and sexual violence.\n\nJessica Taylor, 20, vanished in 2003 while working as an escort in New York City. Some of her remains were discovered in Manorville that year. Other remains were found in a 2011 search of the beach scrub by the side of Ocean Parkway, the road where the other Gilgo Beach victims were found.\n\nInvestigators in April also spent days searching a property in the eastern Long Island hamlet of North Sea, where the Costilla's body was discovered in 1993. Costilla was 28 when she was killed and had lived in New York City.\n\nA decade ago, Suffolk County prosecutors said publicly that they believed Costilla had been killed by a carpenter who lived in the area, John Bittrolff, who was convicted of murdering two other women whose bodies had been found on the same part of Long Island. But Bittrolff was never charged with Costilla's death due to lack of evidence. He insists he is innocent of any murders.\n\nHeuermann's lawyer and the lawyers separately representing his wife and two adult children declined to comment.\n\nHeuermann, who has been in custody since his arrest, has pleaded not guilty. He had been set to return to court on July 30 for a status hearing. No trial date has been set.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nRelated Headlines\n\nFor the first time, daughter of Long Island serial killer victim from Maine speaks out\n\nComments are not available on this {"uri": "2024-06-380131565", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "21:23:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T21:23:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T21:15:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/06/05/us/gilgo-beach-murder-rex-heurmann-additional-killings/index.html", "title": "Gilgo Beach killings suspect expected to be indicted in killings of 2 additional women, sources say", "body": "Alleged Gilgo serial killer Rex Heuermann is expected in a New York court Thursday, according to the Suffolk County district attorney's office.\n\nRex Heuermann, the suspect in the Gilgo Beach killings, is expected to be indicted Thursday on new murder charges in the killings of two additional women, multiple law enforcement sources tell CNN.\n\nThe former New York architect was taken into custody last July and has already been charged with murder in the deaths of four women who have come to be known as the \"Gilgo Four.\"\n\nLaw enforcement officials say the murder charges are related two additional victims, Jessica Taylor and Valerie Mack, and come from a sweeping expansion of the investigation into Heuermann following his arrest last summer.\n\nHeuermann's arrest kicked off a media frenzy, with many wondering whether police had finally caught what the Gilgo Beach community had long feared was a serial killer responsible for a string of unsolved killings that took place over decades.\n\nAt least 11 sets of human remains have been found on Long Island's Suffolk County, including the four women Heuermann has been charged with killing: Melissa Barthelemy, Megan Waterman, Amber Costello and Maureen Brainard-Barnes.\n\nHeuermann was charged with three deaths in 2023 and with the death of Brainard-Barnes in January. He has pleaded not guilty to all murder charges and is being held without bail.\n\nHis attorney, Michael Brown, told reporters in January that Heuermann maintains his innocence and is looking forward to fighting the charges.\n\nThe Suffolk County District Attorney's office confirmed Heuermann is expected in court Thursday.\n\n\"There were a number of necessary investigative steps that were taken,\" District Attorney Raymond Tierney said Monday at an unrelated news conference. \"Thursday, you will see the fruits of that investigation.\"\n\nCNN affiliate WABC reported that police recently searched Long Island's Manorville and North Sea in connection with the investigation, where the remains of three women were found years ago.\n\nThe remains of Gilgo Beach victims Taylor and Mack were found in Manorville, according to police.\n\nMack was a 24-year-old Philadelphia mother who went missing over 20 years ago and whose partial remains were discovered in 2000, authorities said. Police said Taylor's partial remains were found in 2003.\n\nJohn Ray, a lawyer who represents Taylor's family, previously said he did not know whether Heuermann was connected to Taylor's death.\n\nWABC reported that the body of 28-year-old Sandra Costilla was found in North Sea in 1993.\n\nAuthorities recently returned to Heuermann's Massapequa home to execute a search warrant, according to an attorney for his estranged wife, Asa Ellerup.\n\nPhil Marcelo/AP\n\n'A flood of evidence'\n\nAfter Heuermann's arrest last summer, police said the investigation was far from over. They zeroed in on the Massapequa home where he had lived quietly for years with his wife, daughter and stepson.\n\nInvestigators used police dogs and ground-penetrating radar to search the home in July, uncovering over 280 firearms, more than 40 of which were possessed illegally, police said.\n\nAuthorities also looked into areas in Las Vegas and South Carolina where Heuermann owned property.\n\nTierney told reporters last summer that investigators were working with \"a flood of evidence.\"\n\nA few weeks ago, police once again searched the Massapequa home and were seen carrying boxes out of the house. Robert Macedonia, the attorney of Heuermann's estranged wife Asa Ellerup, confirmed that police had a warrant for the search.\n\nEllerup filed for divorce days after Heuermann's arrest last year, but still visits him weekly, according to a statement released by her attorneys in March.\n\nShe maintains that Heuermann is not capable of the crimes he's accused of, the statement said, adding that her sympathies go out to the victims and their families.\n\n\"Nobody deserves to die in that manner,\" Ellerup said in the statement.\n\nCNN's Mark Morales, Emma Tucker and Jean Casarez contributed to {"uri": "8165133924", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "17:36:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T17:36:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T17:36:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.delcotimes.com/2024/06/06/man-charged-in-gilgo-beach-serial-killings-kept-blueprint-of-crimes-on-computer-prosecutors-say/", "title": "Man charged in Gilgo Beach serial killings kept 'blueprint' of crimes on computer, prosecutors say", "body": "RIVERHEAD, N.Y. (AP) -- The New York architect accused of murdering multiple women and leaving their corpses scattered along the Long Island coast kept a \"blueprint\" of his crimes on his computer, prosecutors revealed Thursday as they brought charges against Rex Heuermann in two more killings.\n\nHeuermann, 60, appeared before a judge to be arraigned in the deaths of Jessica Taylor and Sandra Costilla, two young women who were long suspected of being the victims of men preying on sex workers. He had previously been charged with murdering four other women in a string of deaths known as the Gilgo Beach serial killings.\n\nTaylor disappeared in 2003. Costilla was killed 30 years ago, in 1993, and her inclusion in the case indicates that prosecutors now believe Heuermann was killing women for much longer than previously thought.\n\nThe new charges came just days after police finished extensive searches of Heuermann's Massapequa Park home and a wooded area on Long Island tied to the investigation.\n\nIn a court filing, prosecutors said they were able to use new forensic testing methods to match hairs found on or near the vicinity of both victims to a DNA profile that is a likely match to Heuermann. Additionally, prosecutors say they recovered a file on a hard drive in his basement used to \"methodically blueprint\" his killings.\n\nThe all-caps document features a series of checklists with tasks to complete before, during and after the killings, as well as practical lessons for \"next time.\" Among the dozens of entries written are reminders to clean the bodies and destroy evidence, to \"get sleep before hunt\" and to \"have story set.\"\n\nOne section, titled \"things to remember,\" appears to highlight lessons from previous killings, prosecutors said, such as using heavier rope and limiting noise in order to maximize \"play time.\" A \"body prep\" checklist includes, among other items, a note to \"remove head and hands.\"\n\nProsecutors believe that entry may connect Heuermann to yet another victim, Valerie Mack, whose partial skeletal remains were discovered near the body of Taylor after her disappearance in 2000.\n\nHeuermann has not been charged in the death of Mack. But asked during a news conference after Thursday's hearing if he was a suspect, District Attorney Ray Tierney replied, \"That's fair to say.\"\n\nHeuermann pleaded not guilty to killing Taylor and Costilla during the hearing and was ordered held without bail. His lawyer, Michael Brown, said outside court that Heuermann is \"obviously in a bad place in terms of the new charges.\"\n\nAfterward, Tierney said the additional charges provide \"some small measure of closure\" for the victims' families.\n\nSince late 2010, police have been investigating the deaths of at least 10 people -- mostly female sex workers -- whose remains were discovered along an isolated highway not far from Gilgo Beach on Long Island's south shore.\n\nThose victims had disappeared over a span of at least 14 years. Vexed police officers made only halting progress in identifying possible suspects. Investigators long said it was likely that not all of the deaths were the work of the same killer. Some of the victims disappeared in the mid-1990s. Investigators concluded that an 11th person who disappeared in 2010 from the barrier island community of Oak Beach had accidentally drowned.\n\nHeuermann, who lived across a bay from where the bodies were found, was arrested last July. Prosecutors said a new investigative task force used mobile phone location data and DNA samples to link the architect to some of the victims. He was charged with killing four of the women: Megan Waterman, Melissa Barthelemy, Amber Lynn Costello and Maureen Brainard-Barnes.\n\nInvestigators who had searched Heuermann's home extensively and dug up his yard last summer returned to the house again last month and spent nearly a week searching it again. They focused their efforts mostly in the basement, according to a lawyer for Heuermann's wife.\n\nThat followed a search in April of a wooded area in Manorville, about 40 miles (65 kilometers) east of Heuermann's home, and in the Southampton hamlet of North Sea, where Costilla's remains were discovered decades ago.\n\nTierney said the planning document was recovered in March of this year, providing the impetus for the recent searches.\n\nProsecutors also said they found a book in Heuermann's possession by the retired FBI agent John Douglas, \"The Cases That Haunt Us.\" They say the planning document referenced specific pages in another work by Douglas, \"Mind Hunter,\" that allude to the personality types of serial killers and profiles of those who use mutilation and sexual violence.\n\nJessica Taylor, 20, vanished in 2003 while working as an escort in New York City. Some of her remains were discovered in Manorville that year. Other remains were found in a 2011 search of the beach scrub by the side of Ocean Parkway, the road where the other Gilgo Beach victims were found.\n\nTaylor's mother, Elizabeth Baczkiel, was at the courthouse for Thursday's court hearing. She held up childhood photos of her daughter but didn't speak to reporters. Her lawyer, Gloria Allred, read a statement from Baczkiel in which she described her daughter as \"loving, compassionate and so funny,\" and said she would have made a great mother.\n\n\"My darling daughter, you will never be forgotten,\" the statement said. \"You will forever be in our hearts.\"\n\nValerie Mack, 24, who had been working as an escort in Philadelphia, disappeared in 2000 and was last seen by her family in Port Republic, New Jersey, near Atlantic City. Some of her skeletal remains were discovered that same year in the Manorville woods. More of her remains were found in 2011 in the search around Gilgo Beach.\n\nInitially known as \"Jane Doe No. 6,\" Mack's remains had been unidentified for years until genetic testing revealed her identity in 2020.\n\nCostilla was 28 when she was killed and had lived in New York City.\n\nA decade ago, Suffolk County prosecutors said publicly that they believed Costilla had been killed by a carpenter who lived in the area, John Bittrolff, who was convicted of murdering two other women whose bodies had been found on the same part of Long Island. But Bittrolff was never charged with Costilla's death due to lack of evidence. He insists he is innocent of any murders.\n\nHeuermann's lawyer, Brown, said he planned to request the prosecution's files on Bittrolff.\n\n\"Quite frankly, the police department and the district attorney's office all had the finger pointed at Bittrolff for that murder,\" he said. ___", "source": {"uri": "delcotimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Delaware County Daily Times"}, {"uri": "8164880280", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:37:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:37:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:37:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/suspect-in-long-island-serial-killings-charged-over-deaths-of-two-more-women-1634472.html", "title": "Suspect in Long Island serial killings charged over deaths of two more women | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "A New York architect previously accused of killing four women and leaving their corpses scattered along a coastal highway has been charged over the deaths of two more women.\n\nRex Heuermann, 60, is to appear before a judge to face charges that he killed Jessica Taylor and Sandra Costilla, two young women who were long suspected of being the victims of men preying on sex workers.\n\nMs Taylor disappeared in 2003 and Ms Costilla was killed in 1993.\n\nThe new charges came days after police finished extensive searches of Heuermann's Massapequa Park home and a wooded area on Long Island tied to the investigation of a string of deaths known as the Gilgo Beach serial killings.\n\nIn a court filing, prosecutors said new forensic testing methods had matched hairs found on or near both victims to a DNA profile that is a likely match to Heuermann.\n\nProsecutors also say they discovered a \"planning document\" on the hard drive found in his basement used to \"methodically blueprint\" his killings.\n\nThe document includes Heuermann's concerns about leaving forensic evidence, guidance for cleaning and washing bodies, and notes on how to improve \"next time\", according to the bail application\n\nSuffolk County district attorney Ray Tierney plans to hold a news conference after the court hearing.\n\nThe charges involving Ms Costilla, who was killed 30 years ago, indicate that prosecutors believe Heuermann was killing victims for much longer longer than previously thought.\n\nSince late 2010, police have been investigating the deaths of at least 10 people -- mostly female sex workers -- whose remains were discovered along an isolated highway not far from Gilgo Beach on Long Island's south shore.\n\nThe victims had disappeared over a span of at least 14 years, and police made only halting progress in identifying possible suspects. Investigators long said it was likely that not all of the deaths were the work of the same killer.\n\nSome of the victims disappeared in the mid-1990s, and investigators concluded that an 11th person who disappeared in 2010 from the barrier island community of Oak Beach had accidentally drowned.\n\nHeuermann, who lived across a bay from where the bodies were found, was arrested last July.\n\nProsecutors said a new investigative taskforce used mobile phone location data and DNA samples to link the architect to some of the victims. He was charged with killing four of the women: Megan Waterman, Melissa Barthelemy, Amber Lynn Costello and Maureen Brainard-Barnes.\n\nInvestigators who had searched Heuermann's home extensively and dug up his yard last summer returned to the house again last month and spent nearly a week searching it again. They focused mostly in the basement, according to a lawyer for Heuermann's wife.\n\nThat followed a search in April of a wooded area in Manorville, about 40 miles east of Heuermann's home, linked to another Gilgo Beach victim.\n\nMs Taylor, 20, vanished in 2003 while working as an escort in New York City. Some of her remains were discovered in Manorville that year.\n\nOther remains were found in a 2011 search of the beach scrub by the side of Ocean Parkway, the road where the other Gilgo Beach victims were found.\n\nInvestigators in April also spent days searching a property in the eastern Long Island hamlet of North Sea, where Ms Costilla's body was discovered in 1993. She was 28 when she was killed and had lived in New York City.\n\nA decade ago, Suffolk County prosecutors said publicly that they believed she had been killed by a carpenter who lived in the area, John Bittrolff, who was convicted of murdering two other women whose bodies had been found on the same part of Long Island. But he was never charged with Ms Costilla's death due to lack of evidence, and insists he is innocent of any murders.\n\nHeuermann, who has been in custody since his arrest, has pleaded not guilty. He had been set to return to court on June 18 for a status hearing. No trial date has been set.", "source": {"uri": "breakingnews.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breaking News.ie"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8164859987", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:24:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:24:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:24:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.expressandstar.com/news/world-news/2024/06/06/suspect-in-long-island-serial-killings-charged-over-deaths-of-two-more-women/", "title": "Suspect in Long Island serial killings charged over deaths of two more women", "body": "Police have been investigating the deaths of at least 10 people near Gilgo Beach.\n\nA New York architect previously accused of killing four women and leaving their corpses scattered along a coastal highway has been charged over the deaths of two more women.\n\nRex Heuermann, 60, is to appear before a judge to face charges that he killed Jessica Taylor and Sandra Costilla, two young women who were long suspected of being the victims of men preying on sex workers.\n\nMs Taylor disappeared in 2003 and Ms Costilla was killed in 1993.\n\nThe new charges came days after police finished extensive searches of Heuermann's Massapequa Park home and a wooded area on Long Island tied to the investigation of a string of deaths known as the Gilgo Beach serial killings.\n\nIn a court filing, prosecutors said new forensic testing methods had matched hairs found on or near both victims to a DNA profile that is a likely match to Heuermann.\n\nProsecutors also say they discovered a \"planning document\" on the hard drive found in his basement used to \"methodically blueprint\" his killings.\n\nThe document includes Heuermann's concerns about leaving forensic evidence, guidance for cleaning and washing bodies, and notes on how to improve \"next time\", according to the bail application\n\nSuffolk County district attorney Ray Tierney plans to hold a news conference after the court hearing.\n\nThe charges involving Ms Costilla, who was killed 30 years ago, indicate that prosecutors believe Heuermann was killing victims for much longer longer than previously thought.\n\nSince late 2010, police have been investigating the deaths of at least 10 people -- mostly female sex workers -- whose remains were discovered along an isolated highway not far from Gilgo Beach on Long Island's south shore.\n\nThe victims had disappeared over a span of at least 14 years, and police made only halting progress in identifying possible suspects. Investigators long said it was likely that not all of the deaths were the work of the same killer.\n\nSome of the victims disappeared in the mid-1990s, and investigators concluded that an 11th person who disappeared in 2010 from the barrier island community of Oak Beach had accidentally drowned.\n\nHeuermann, who lived across a bay from where the bodies were found, was arrested last July.\n\nProsecutors said a new investigative taskforce used mobile phone location data and DNA samples to link the architect to some of the victims. He was charged with killing four of the women: Megan Waterman, Melissa Barthelemy, Amber Lynn Costello and Maureen Brainard-Barnes.\n\nInvestigators who had searched Heuermann's home extensively and dug up his yard last summer returned to the house again last month and spent nearly a week searching it again. They focused mostly in the basement, according to a lawyer for Heuermann's wife.\n\nThat followed a search in April of a wooded area in Manorville, about 40 miles east of Heuermann's home, linked to another Gilgo Beach victim.\n\nMs Taylor, 20, vanished in 2003 while working as an escort in New York City. Some of her remains were discovered in Manorville that year.\n\nOther remains were found in a 2011 search of the beach scrub by the side of Ocean Parkway, the road where the other Gilgo Beach victims were found.\n\nInvestigators in April also spent days searching a property in the eastern Long Island hamlet of North Sea, where Ms Costilla's body was discovered in 1993. She was 28 when she was killed and had lived in New York City.\n\nA decade ago, Suffolk County prosecutors said publicly that they believed she had been killed by a carpenter who lived in the area, John Bittrolff, who was convicted of murdering two other women whose bodies had been found on the same part of Long Island. But he was never charged with Ms Costilla's death due to lack of evidence, and insists he is innocent of any murders.\n\nHeuermann, who has been in custody since his arrest, has pleaded not guilty. He had been set to return to court on June 18 for a status hearing. {"uri": "8164765964", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "13:27:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T13:27:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T13:26:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/chicago/news/gilgo-beach-murders-rex-heuermann-new-murder-charges/", "title": "Gilgo Beach murders suspect Rex Heuermann charged in killings of 2 more women", "body": "RIVERHEAD, N.Y. -- Gilgo Beach murders suspect Rex Heuermann is now charged in the killings of two more women on Long Island.\n\nHeuermann was due in Suffolk County Court at 9:30 a.m. in Riverhead, New York. He was previously facing charges in four other murders and has pleaded not guilty in those cases.\n\nThursday's court appearance comes after investigators scoured the Manorville Pine Barrens in April. The partial remains of Valerie Mack were discovered there in 2000, and three years later, partial remains belonging to Jessica Taylor were also found in the area. Additional remains of Mack and Taylor, who both worked as escorts, were found near Gilgo Beach.\n\nAround the same time in April, the search led investigators to North Sea, a hamlet in Southampton, where Sandra Costilla was found dead in 1993. Prosecutors previously linked her death to Manorville carpenter John Bittrolff, who was later convicted of killing two other women.\n\nInvestigators then returned to Heuermann's Massapequa Park home in May to look for new evidence. Law enforcement previously seized hundreds of electronic devices from the home, some which, court documents suggest, Heuermann allegedly used to contact and research sex workers. Investigators also seized nearly 300 guns from the home and were seen digging in the backyard in the days following Heuermann's July 2023 arrest.\n\nSuffolk County District Attorney Ray Tierney is expected to share more details about the new charges around 11 a.m.\n\nHeuermann was arrested on July 14, 2023 and charged with the murders of Melissa Barthelemy, Megan Waterman and Amber Costello. In January, new charges were filed against him in connection to the murder of Maureen Brainard-Barnes.\n\nThe four women's remains were found in shallow graves near Gilgo Beach in 2010. All four were sex workers who went missing between 2007-2010.\n\nProsecutors said DNA evidence and burner phones tied Heuermann to the murders. Heuermann is being held without bail and has been behind bars for nearly a year.\n\nThe remains of 11 people were found near Gilgo Beach between 1996-2011.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", {"uri": "2024-06-381007063", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:39:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:39:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T08:59:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.weareiowa.com/article/news/nation-world/gilgo-beach-serial-killings-suspect-more-charges-new-details/507-c4eccd1b-80d0-4fb4-b9c4-316be202c63f", "title": "Suspect in Long Island's Gilgo Beach serial killings is charged in the deaths of two more women", "body": "RIVERHEAD, N.Y. -- The New York architect previously accused of murdering four women and leaving their corpses scattered along a coastal highway was charged Thursday in the deaths of two more women.\n\nRex Heuermann, 60, was set to appear before a judge to face charges that he murdered Jessica Taylor and Sandra Costilla. Taylor disappeared in the early 2000s. Costilla was killed in 1993. The new charges came just days after police finished extensive searches of Heuermann's Massapequa Park home and a wooded area on Long Island tied to the investigation of a string of deaths known as the Gilgo Beach serial killings.\n\nSuffolk County District Attorney Ray Tierney planned to hold a news conference following the court hearing.\n\nSince late 2010, police have been investigating the deaths of at least 10 people -- mostly female sex workers -- whose remains were discovered along an isolated highway not far from Gilgo Beach on Long Island's south shore.\n\nThe victims had disappeared over a span of at least 14 years. Vexed police officers made only halting progress in identifying possible suspects. Investigators long said it was likely that not all of the deaths were the work of the same killer. Some of the victims disappeared in the mid-1990s. Investigators concluded that an 11th person who disappeared in 2010 from the barrier island community of Oak Beach had accidentally drowned.\n\nHeuermann, who lived across a bay from where the bodies were found, was arrested last July. Prosecutors said a new investigative task force used mobile phone location data and DNA samples to link the architect to some of the victims. He was charged with killing four of the women: Megan Waterman, Melissa Barthelemy, Amber Lynn Costello and Maureen Brainard-Barnes.\n\nInvestigators who had searched Heuermann's home extensively and dug up his yard last summer returned to the house again last month and spent nearly a week searching it again. They focused their efforts mostly in the basement, according to a lawyer for Heuermann's wife.\n\nThat followed a search in April of a wooded area in Manorville, about 40 miles (65 kilometers) east of Heuermann's home, linked to another Gilgo Beach victim.\n\nJessica Taylor, 20, vanished in 2003 while working as an escort in New York City. Some of her remains were discovered in Manorville that year. Other remains were found in a 2011 search of the beach scrub by the side of Ocean Parkway, the road where the other Gilgo Beach victims were found.\n\nInvestigators in April also spent days searching a property in the eastern Long Island hamlet of North Sea, where the Costilla's body was discovered in 1993. Costilla was 28 when she was killed and had lived in New York City.\n\nA decade ago, Suffolk County prosecutors said publicly that they believed Costilla had been killed by a carpenter who lived in the area, John Bittrolff, who was convicted of murdering two other women whose bodies had been found on the same part of Long Island. But Bittrolff was never charged with Costilla's death due to lack of evidence. He insists he is innocent of any murders.\n\nHeuermann's lawyer and the lawyers separately representing his wife and two adult children declined to comment.\n\nHeuermann, who has been in custody since his arrest, has pleaded not guilty. He had been set to return to court on June 18 for a status hearing. No trial date has been set.", "source": {"uri": "weareiowa.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Local 5 - weareiowa.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Taylor and Valerie Mack on Thursday.\n\nThe headless and handless body of Taylor, 20, was discovered in the woods of Manorville, New York, in 2000.\n\nIn 2011, the rest of her remains were discovered over 40 miles away near Gilgo Beach on Long Island.\n\nMack had vanished near Atlantic City, New Jersey, in 2000 at the age of 24 and was also found dead in Manorville, with parts of her later were seen sweeping the wooded area in Manorville over three days.\n\nLast month, detectives also went back to search the alleged serial killer's Long Island home.\n\nOfficers had recovered a cache of weapons during an initial search following his arrest last summer.\n\nHeuermann was arrested in July and initially charged with killing Melissa Barthelemy, 24, Megan Waterman, 22, and Amber Lynn Costello 27.\n\nIn February, he was also charged with the murder of Maureen Brainard-Barnes, 25.\n\nThe women were found wrapped in burlap and buried along the remote stretch of Ocean Parkway on Long Island's South Shore over a decade ago.\n\nHeuermann, an architect, has pleaded not guilty to all counts and currently remains in jail awaiting trial. A date for trial has not yet been set.\n\nThe Gilgo women's remains were discovered during the search for 23-year-old Shannan Gilbert, an escort from New Jersey who had vanished in May 2010 after making a frantic 911 call.\n\nIn April, officials searched a Manorville area where the partial remains of Taylor and Mack were found more than 20 years ago\n\nThe first victim, 24-year-old Melissa Barthelemy, was discovered by Suffolk County Police on December 11, 2010. The body of Megan Waterman, 22, from Maine, was found two days later\n\nHeuermann is also charged with killing Amber Costello (left) and Maureen Brainard-Barnes (right)\n\nHer remains were found along the same stretch of coast in December 2011 - and it was her body that led police to the discovery of the 'Gilgo Four'.\n\nNo one has ever been charged in Gilbert's death and police said it may have been accidental - but her family believe she was murdered.\n\nThe women were among 11 found on the desolate stretch of coastline close to Heuermann's Long Island Home between 2010 and 2011.\n\nAll of the victims worked as escorts who advertised themselves on Craigslist.\n\nHeuermann was linked to the killings by DNA on the burlap used to transport the bodied which was compared to samples taken from a pizza crust and napkin that were discarded outside his Manhattan architectural firm, police said.\n\nThe samples boasted a 99.96 percent match, according to law enforcement officials.\n\nCops said they were alerted to Heuermann as a potential suspect after a witness linked Heuermann's Chevrolet Avalanche to Costello's murder.\n\nThe women known as the 'Gilgo Four' were discovered close to Heuermann's Long Island home. However, other bodies - including those of sex workers - have been found in the area\n\nThe car was then tied to Heuermann's cellphone records, which allegedly linked him to locations related to the murders.\n\nThe indictment stated that Heuermann had used different burner phones to contact each of his victims.\n\nCops also accused Heuermann of using Barthelemy's phone to make taunting phone calls to her family from the comfort of his office.\n\nHer sister Melissa told how she was bombarded with threatening phone calls from the killer who boasted of the killing and was keeping tabs on her movements.\n\nVess Mitev, a lawyer for Heuermann's two adult children, said the family was closely monitoring the developments.\n\n'The hearing is yet another mile marker in this macabre saga, where {"uri": "2024-06-380821165", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:02:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:02:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T11:59:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/newyork/news/gilgo-beach-murders-rex-heuermann-new-murder-charges/", "title": "Gilgo Beach murders suspect Rex Heuermann set to face 2 new charges today in court", "body": "Heuermann is due in Suffolk County Court at 9:30 a.m. in Riverhead, New York. He is currently facing charges in four other murders and has pleaded not guilty in those cases.\n\nThursday's court appearance comes after investigators scoured the Manorville Pine Barrens in April. The partial remains of Valerie Mack were discovered there in 2000, and three years later, partial remains belonging to Jessica Taylor were also found in the area. Additional remains of Mack and Taylor, who both worked as escorts, were found near Gilgo Beach.\n\nAround the same time in April, the search led investigators to North Sea, a hamlet in Southampton, where Sandra Costilla was found dead in 1993. Prosecutors previously linked her death to Manorville carpenter John Bittrolff, who was later convicted of killing two other women.\n\nInvestigators then returned to Heuermann's Massapequa Park home in May to look for new evidence. Law enforcement previously seized hundreds of electronic devices from the home, some which, court documents suggest, Heuermann allegedly used to contact and research sex workers. Investigators also seized nearly 300 guns from the home and were seen digging in the backyard in the days following Heuermann's July 2023 arrest.\n\nSuffolk County District Attorney Ray Tierney is expected to share more details about the new charges following the hearing around 11 a.m.\n\nRex Heuermann charged in connection to Gilgo Beach murders\n\nHeuermann was arrested on July 14, 2023 and charged with the murders of Melissa Barthelemy, Megan Waterman and Amber Costello. In January, new charges were filed against him in connection to the murder of Maureen Brainard-Barnes.\n\nThe four women's remains were found in shallow graves near Gilgo Beach in 2010. All four were sex workers who went missing between 2007-2010.\n\nProsecutors said DNA evidence and burner phones tied Heuermann to the murders. Heuermann is being held without bail and has been behind bars for nearly a year.\n\nThe remains of 11 people were found near Gilgo Beach between 1996-2011.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", {"uri": "8163659477", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "22:40:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T22:40:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T22:31:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://kion546.com/news/national-world/cnn-national/2024/06/05/gilgo-beach-killings-suspect-expected-to-be-indicted-in-killings-of-2-additional-women-sources-say/", "title": "Gilgo Beach killings suspect expected to be indicted in killings of 2 additional women, sources say - KION546", "body": "By John Miller, Mark Morales, Brynn Gingras and Lauren Mascarenhas, CNN\n\n(CNN) -- Rex Heuermann, the suspect in the Gilgo Beach killings, is expected to be indicted Thursday on new murder charges in the killings of two additional women, multiple law enforcement sources tell CNN.\n\nThe former New York architect was taken into custody in July and has already been charged with murder in the deaths of four women who have come to be known as the \"Gilgo Four.\"\n\nLaw enforcement officials say the new murder charges are related to two additional victims, Jessica Taylor and Valerie Mack, and come from a sweeping expansion of the investigation into Heuermann following his arrest last summer.\n\nHeuermann's arrest kicked off a media frenzy, with many wondering whether police had finally caught what the Gilgo Beach community had long feared was a serial killer responsible for a string of unsolved killings that took place over decades.\n\nAt least 11 sets of human remains have been found on Long Island's Suffolk County, including the four women Heuermann has been charged with killing: Melissa Barthelemy, Megan Waterman, Amber Costello and Maureen Brainard-Barnes.\n\nHeuermann was charged with three deaths in 2023 and with the death of Brainard-Barnes in January. He has pleaded not guilty to all murder charges and is being held without bail.\n\nHis attorney, Michael Brown, told reporters in January that Heuermann maintains his innocence and is looking forward to fighting the charges.\n\nCNN affiliate WABC reported police recently searched Long Island's Manorville and North Sea in connection with the investigation, where the remains of three women were found years ago.\n\nInvestigators uncovered evidence in the searches of Manorville and Heuermann's home earlier this year that helped advance the investigation, according to the law enforcement sources.\n\nThe remains of Taylor and Mack were found in Manorville, according to police. Manorville, a community in eastern Long Island, is about 40 miles northeast of where the bodies of the \"Gilgo Four\" were discovered.\n\nMack was a 24-year-old Philadelphia mother who went missing in 2000 and whose partial remains were discovered in the Manorville woods later that year. More remains that matched her DNA were recovered along the marshy area of Gilgo Beach in 2011.\n\nartial remains belonging to 20-year-old Taylor were found in Manorville in 2003, and additional remains were found on Gilgo Beach in 2011.\n\nJohn Ray, a lawyer who represents Taylor's family, previously said he did not know whether Heuermann was connected to Taylor's death.\n\nThe search in North Sea - roughly 65 miles northeast of Gilgo Beach - was related to the unsolved murder of 28-year-old Sandra Costilla, whose body was found in a wooded area of North Sea in 1993, the law enforcement sources told CNN. Suffolk County Police are investigating to see if Costilla's murder is connected to Heuermann, the sources said.\n\nAfter Heuermann's arrest last summer, police said the investigation was far from over. They zeroed in on the Massapequa home where he had lived quietly for years with his wife, daughter and stepson.\n\nInvestigators used police dogs and ground-penetrating radar to search the home in July, uncovering over 280 firearms, more than 40 of which were possessed illegally, police said.\n\nAuthorities also looked into areas in Las Vegas and South Carolina where Heuermann owned property.\n\nTierney told reporters last summer that investigators were working with \"a flood of evidence.\"\n\nA few weeks ago, police once again searched the Massapequa home and were seen carrying boxes out of the house. Robert Macedonia, the attorney of Heuermann's estranged wife Asa Ellerup, confirmed that police had a warrant for the search.\n\nEllerup filed for divorce days after Heuermann's arrest last year, but still visits him weekly, according to a statement released by her attorneys in March.\n\nShe maintains that Heuermann is not capable of the crimes he's accused of, the statement said, adding that her sympathies go out to the victims and their families.\n\n\"Nobody deserves to die in that manner,\" Ellerup said in the statement.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "8164864190", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:28:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:28:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:27:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/world/arid-41410769.html", "title": "Suspect in Long Island serial killings charged over deaths of two more women", "body": "Rex Heuermann, 60, is to appear before a judge to face charges that he killed Jessica Taylor and Sandra Costilla, two young women who were long suspected of being the victims of men preying on sex workers.\n\nMs Taylor disappeared in 2003 and Ms Costilla was killed in 1993.\n\nThe new charges came days after police finished extensive searches of Heuermann's Massapequa Park home and a wooded area on Long Island tied to the investigation of a string of deaths known as the Gilgo Beach serial killings.\n\nIn a court filing, prosecutors said new forensic testing methods had matched hairs found on or near both victims to a DNA profile that is a likely match to Heuermann.\n\nProsecutors also say they discovered a \"planning document\" on the hard drive found in his basement used to \"methodically blueprint\" his killings.\n\nThe document includes Heuermann's concerns about leaving forensic evidence, guidance for cleaning and washing bodies, and notes on how to improve \"next time\", according to the bail application\n\nSuffolk County district attorney Ray Tierney plans to hold a news conference after the court hearing.\n\nThe charges involving Ms Costilla, who was killed 30 years ago, indicate that prosecutors believe Heuermann was killing victims for much longer longer than previously thought.\n\nSince late 2010, police have been investigating the deaths of at least 10 people -- mostly female sex workers -- whose remains were discovered along an isolated highway not far from Gilgo Beach on Long Island's south shore.\n\nThe victims had disappeared over a span of at least 14 years, and police made only halting progress in identifying possible suspects. Investigators long said it was likely that not all of the deaths were the work of the same killer.\n\nSome of the victims disappeared in the mid-1990s, and investigators concluded that an 11th person who disappeared in 2010 from the barrier island community of Oak Beach had accidentally drowned.\n\nHeuermann, who lived across a bay from where the bodies were found, was arrested last July.\n\nProsecutors said a new investigative taskforce used mobile phone location data and DNA samples to link the architect to some of the victims. He was charged with killing four of the women: Megan Waterman, Melissa Barthelemy, Amber Lynn Costello and Maureen Brainard-Barnes.\n\nInvestigators who had searched Heuermann's home extensively and dug up his yard last summer returned to the house again last month and spent nearly a week searching it again. They focused mostly in the basement, according to a lawyer for Heuermann's wife.\n\nThat followed a search in April of a wooded area in Manorville, about 40 miles east of Heuermann's home, linked to another Gilgo Beach victim.\n\nMs Taylor, 20, vanished in 2003 while working as an escort in New York City. Some of her remains were discovered in Manorville that year.\n\nOther remains were found in a 2011 search of the beach scrub by the side of Ocean Parkway, the road where the other Gilgo Beach victims were found.\n\nInvestigators in April also spent days searching a property in the eastern Long Island hamlet of North Sea, where Ms Costilla's body was discovered in 1993. She was 28 when she was killed and had lived in New York City.\n\nA decade ago, Suffolk County prosecutors said publicly that they believed she had been killed by a carpenter who lived in the area, John Bittrolff, who was convicted of murdering two other women whose bodies had been found on the same part of Long Island. But he was never charged with Ms Costilla's death due to lack of evidence, and insists he is innocent of any murders.\n\nHeuermann, who has been in custody since his arrest, has pleaded not guilty. He had been set to return to court on June 18 for a status hearing. No trial date has been set.", "source": {"uri": "irishexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish Examiner"}, "authors": [{"uri": "philip_marcelo@irishexaminer.com", "name": "Philip Marcelo", {"uri": "8164784826", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "13:39:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T13:39:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T13:38:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://weisradio.com/2024/06/06/gilgo-beach-suspect-rex-heuermann-charged-in-two-more-murders-alleged-crimes-now-date-back-to-1993/", "title": "Gilgo Beach suspect Rex Heuermann charged in two more murders, alleged crimes now date back to 1993 - WEIS | Local & Area News, Sports, & Weather", "body": "(NEW YORK) -- Gilgo Beach suspect Rex Heuermann has been charged with two additional murders and is now accused of killing six women dating as far back as 1993, according to a court document unsealed Thursday.\n\nHeuermann is accused of the 2003 murder of Jessica Taylor, whose remains were found on Long Island in Gilgo Beach and in Manorville, and accused of the 1993 murder of Sandra Costilla, whose remains were found in North Sea, Long Island, in 1993, according to court documents.\n\nThese developments significantly expand the timeline in the Gilgo Beach case.\n\nInvestigators searched Heuermann's Long Island home as recently as May. Authorities also searched a wooded area in Manorville on Long Island in April as part of the investigation, according to law enforcement sources.\n\nHeuermann, an architect and father, was arrested in July and initially charged with murdering three escorts: Megan Waterman, Amber Costello and Melissa Barthelemy. He was charged in January with the murder of a fourth escort, Maureen Brainard-Barnes.\n\nThe remains of all four women were found in 2010 in desolate spots along the ocean near Gilgo Beach. Six additional sets of remains were also found in the area.\n\nHeuermann pleaded not guilty to the four murders.", "source": {"uri": "weisradio.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WEIS"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-06-380974055", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:09:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:09:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T13:52:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/suspect-in-long-island-s-gilgo-beach-serial-killings-is-charged-in-the-deaths-of/article_e59104e9-52b6-5aab-a015-8b3ad6376e18.html", "title": "Suspect in Long Island's Gilgo Beach serial killings is charged in the deaths of two more women", "body": "The New York architect accused of killing four women and leaving their bodies near Long Island's Gilgo Beach has been accused in the deaths of two more women\n\nRIVERHEAD, N.Y. (AP) -- The New York architect previously accused of killing four women and leaving their corpses scattered along a coastal highway was charged Thursday in the deaths of two more women.\n\nRex Heuermann, 60, was set to appear before a judge to face charges that he killed Jessica Taylor and Sandra Costilla, two young women who were long suspected of being the victims of men preying on sex workers.\n\nTaylor disappeared in 2003. Costilla was killed in 1993. The new charges came just days after police finished extensive searches of Heuermann's Massapequa Park home and a wooded area on Long Island tied to the investigation of a string of deaths known as the Gilgo Beach serial killings.\n\nIn a court filing, prosecutors said were able to use new forensic testing methods to match hairs found on or near the vicinity of both victims to a DNA profile that is a likely match to Heuermann. Additionally, prosecutors say they discovered a \"planning document\" on the hard drive found in his basement used to \"methodically blueprint\" his killings.\n\nThe document includes Heuermann's concerns about leaving behind forensic evidence, guidance for cleaning and washing bodies, and notes on how to improve \"next time,\" according to the bail application\n\nSuffolk County District Attorney Ray Tierney planned to hold a news conference following the court hearing.\n\nThe charges involving Costilla, who was killed 30 years ago, indicate that prosecutors believe Heuermann was killing victims for much longer longer than previously thought.\n\nSince late 2010, police have been investigating the deaths of at least 10 people -- mostly female sex workers -- whose remains were discovered along an isolated highway not far from Gilgo Beach on Long Island's south shore.\n\nThe victims had disappeared over a span of at least 14 years. Vexed police officers made only halting progress in identifying possible suspects. Investigators long said it was likely that not all of the deaths were the work of the same killer. Some of the victims disappeared in the mid-1990s. Investigators concluded that an 11th person who disappeared in 2010 from the barrier island community of Oak Beach had accidentally drowned.\n\nHeuermann, who lived across a bay from where the bodies were found, was arrested last July. Prosecutors said a new investigative task force used mobile phone location data and DNA samples to link the architect to some of the victims. He was charged with killing four of the women: Megan Waterman, Melissa Barthelemy, Amber Lynn Costello and Maureen Brainard-Barnes.\n\nInvestigators who had searched Heuermann's home extensively and dug up his yard last summer returned to the house again last month and spent nearly a week searching it again. They focused their efforts mostly in the basement, according to a lawyer for Heuermann's wife.\n\nThat followed a search in April of a wooded area in Manorville, about 40 miles (65 kilometers) east of Heuermann's home, linked to another Gilgo Beach victim.\n\nJessica Taylor, 20, vanished in 2003 while working as an escort in New York City. Some of her remains were discovered in Manorville that year. Other remains were found in a 2011 search of the beach scrub by the side of Ocean Parkway, the road where the other Gilgo Beach victims were found.\n\nInvestigators in April also spent days searching a property in the eastern Long Island hamlet of North Sea, where the Costilla's body was discovered in 1993. Costilla was 28 when she was killed and had lived in New York City.\n\nA decade ago, Suffolk County prosecutors said publicly that they believed Costilla had been killed by a carpenter who lived in the area, John Bittrolff, who was convicted of murdering two other women whose bodies had been found on the same part of Long Island. But Bittrolff was never charged with Costilla's death due to lack of evidence. He insists he is innocent of any murders.\n\nHeuermann's lawyer and the lawyers separately representing his wife and two adult children declined to comment.\n\nHeuermann, who has been in custody since his arrest, has pleaded not guilty. He had been set to return to court on June 18 for a status hearing. No trial date has been set.\n\nFollow Philip Marcelo at twitter.com/philmarcelo.\n\nMore from this section\n\nJohn Driscoll wins Democratic nomination for U.S. House in Montana's 2nd Congressional District\n\nClick n' Close to Receive Top Lender Award at USDA's Single Family Housing Guaranteed Loan Program Ceremony\n\nIntroducing INTENT, Connecting Candidate-Seeking Employers to
